work against the progress of their
female subordinates well this this

so this sprang this this motivated

we phenomenon and over the years we have

the meritocratic system is just another

that queen bee behavior is also quite
to be rewarded so that it's not so

it's something that yields women that
that leads to success so to start with
this first point we wanted to show that
Queen Bee behavior is a response to an
environment that is very masculine that
is negative about women and we did this
from the perspective of a social
psychological theory called social
identity theory Jen also discussed it a
little bit already and what this theory
states is that when well in this case
women are confronted with discrimination
of their group negative stereotypes
about the ability of women to be leaders
they experience a threat to their
identity this can result in lower self
esteem it triggers all kinds of coping
responses and when we look at these
coping responses that you can make a
distinction between collective responses
and individual responses so a collective
response would be to protest to try to
strive for better in in better outcomes
of the in-group for example when you're
a female leader you can join mentoring
groups you can mentor other women to try
to achieve the same thing as you have
achieved that would be a collective
response however in this social identity
identity work what is often fine found
is that people also pursue individual
responses so this is trying to achieve
individual outcomes not necessarily at
at at the expense of the group but often
these these coping strategies do come at
the expense of the group for example
when you strive for better personal
outcomes when you distance yourself from
the group that is negatively stereotyped
in order to be perceived more positively
yourself and when you try to assimilate
into the out group trying to become more
like men for example by showing your
masculine characteristics in an attempt
to show these leadership stereotypes
about women don't apply to me and this
is of course where the queen bee
response fits in so
what we predicted was that queen bee
responses are actually a response to the
social identity threat that women
experience when they are in a work
setting that devalues their gender and
this is because first of all what is an
important predictor there is that when
you look at the research on social
identity group members who have a
relatively low identification tends to
pursue individual mobility responses and
group members who have a relatively high
identification with their group tend to
show collective responses so we
predicted that the queen bee behavior
would be a response to a threatening
work setting but only a response of
women who didn't identify themselves
that much with their gender at work at
least so that was our hypothesis queen
bee behavior is a response of women with
low gender identification who are
confronted with gender bias and we did a

and I'm going to show you one today and
this was a study we did among the police

the police force is a typical very
masculine organization and we this
hypothesis we also tested it in

to show here is an experimental study
where we Prime's women with the presence

in order to see whether that would
trigger queen bee responses so first of
all we measured amongst 63 senior women
in three police organizations we
measured their gender identification at
work so with questions like at work I
identify with other women and then we

influenced their outcomes or in which

very broad description in order to have
to describe all sorts of situations and
in the absent condition we tried to
manipulate a situation that would really
offset social
identity threat so in this condition we
asked them to describe a work situation
in which they had felt that their gender

which their personally personal
qualities had been acknowledged so this
was the way in which we triggered her
offset gender bias crimes social
identity threat what we found is we

behavior would be very masculine
leadership style we asked them how

we found was indeed what we expected
this kind of queen bee responses were
found mostly among women with relatively
low gender identification at work who
had subsequent subsequently been primed

difference between women with low and
high gender identification low
identifiers showing more queen bee

was not the case in the control
condition so in the control condition
there was no difference between low and

did not show now we did more studies
